summary: SARS-CoV belongs to the Coronaviridae family in the Nidovirales order. it is the largest RNA virus (positive stranded) with a genome size of around 30 kb. the viral genes encoded by all coronaviruses, as well as their gene organization, are all similar. studies indicated either M and N or M and E are sufficient for the formation and release of VLPs. in viral envelope, M protein laterally interacts with the other two transmembrane proteins E and S. inhibition on M gene expression might be a good strategy for anti-SARS drug development. the results of current study may provide valuable information for the design of more effective siRNA against the M gene of SARS-CoV. we compared the M genes derived from 15 isolates of SARS-CoV. previously, a number of M gene siRNAs based on random selection have been reported. we chose two unexplored regions that were well conserved in the M genes among the 15 isolates of SARS-CoV. one targeting site was +221+242nt and the other at
